title: E0515 "cannot return value referencing temporary value" no solution given though

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur.
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
use tokio::sync::{Mutex, MutexGuard};
use std::sync::Arc;
use lazy_static::lazy_static;
use std::collections::HashMap;

lazy_static! {
    static ref mutexMap: Mutex<HashMap<String, Arc<Mutex<()>> >> = Mutex::new(HashMap::new());
}

async fn acquire_guard(_dir: &str) -> MutexGuard<'_, ()> {
    let mut mapGuard = mutexMap.lock().await;
    if !mapGuard.contains_key(_dir) {
        let mutex = Arc::new(Mutex::new(()));
        mapGuard.insert(_dir.to_string(), mutex);
    }
    let guard = mapGuard.get(_dir).unwrap().lock().await;
    guard
}

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() {
    let n = "test";
    let guard = acquire_guard(n);
}


```

The current output is:

```rs
error[E0515]: cannot return value referencing temporary value
  --> src/main.rs:18:5
   |
17 |     let guard = mapGuard.to_owned().get(_dir).unwrap().lock().await;
   |                         ----------------------- temporary value created here
18 |     guard
   |     ^^^^^ returns a value referencing data owned by the current function

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0515`.
```

<!-- The following is not always necessary. -->
Ideally the output should look like:

Both temporary value and local value are used interchangeably. Before this error, I was getting the error with the same code but using "local" instead of temporary. Stick to one please or make the connection in the explanation.

The last message should tell the user that they can not only learn more but can solve the error. Except it doesn't help at all.
I followed the "solution" but got this error to being with. I have no idea why the ^^^ is underlying an already created temporary value.
I have no idea how that variable is reference by the return value.
